explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — The macro/function that fetches 'impl' and 'stream' may expand to code that uses string.h routines (e.g. copying names or metadata). Need its definition to see if any memcpy/strcpy/strncpy/etc. are used and with what buffer bounds.
OS_impl_filehandle_table — The table referenced by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its element layout and sizes determine whether any string copies or memory accesses performed by the table lookup are bounds-safe.
OS_stream_table — Same reason as above for the stream lookup: the table layout and element fields (possible char arrays) are needed to check bounds of any string operations.
OS_impl_file_internal_record_t — The structure type for 'impl' (fields beyond fd may include character arrays or pointers). Its member types and sizes are required to verify any string handling on those members.
OS_stream_internal_record_t — The structure type for 'stream' (may contain name fields or other buffers). Required to determine whether any string operations in lookups or later macros access buffers out-of-bounds.
OS_object_token_t — The token type passed to lookups; its layout/encoding can affect how OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET or OS_ObjectIndexFromToken interprets it and whether any derived pointer arithmetic or copying could misuse string functions.
OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — Shown in the static call graph as a callee of this function (via the table-get macro). Its implementation may call or trigger string.h functions; the implementation and its buffer usage must be checked.
OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS — Macro invoked in the function that may expand to code calling helper routines; it could contain string operations or call functions that do. Its expansion is needed to determine if string.h functions are used and whether those uses are bounds-safe.
OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl — Identified in the call graph as a callee (and related to OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS). Its implementation must be inspected for any use of string.h functions and associated buffer sizes/arguments.

These symbols cover the table lookup path and the macro/call that could hide string.h usage. The target function itself contains no explicit string.h calls, so any violation would come from the macros/lookup functions or the invoked flag-setting routine; therefore their definitions and the involved table/record types are necessary to determine compliance with the MISRA rule.
